message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The SCIP Optimization Suite 7.0
Paper Abstract: The SCIP Optimization Suite provides a collection of software packages for mathematical optimization centered around the constraint integer programming framework SCIP. This paper discusses enhancements and extensions contained in version 7.0 of the SCIP Optimization Suite. The new version features the parallel presolving library PaPILO as a new addition to the suite. PaPILO 1.0 simplifies mixed-integer linear optimization problems and can be used stand-alone or integrated into SCIP via a presolver plugin. SCIP 7.0 provides additional support for decomposition algorithms. Besides improvements in the Benders’ decomposition solver of SCIP, user-defined decomposition structures can be read, which are used by the automated Benders’ decomposition solver and two primal heuristics. Additionally, SCIP 7.0 comes with a tree size estimation that is used to predict the completion of the overall solving process and potentially trigger restarts. Moreover, substantial performance improvements of the MIP core were achieved by new developments in presolving, primal heuristics, branching rules, conflict analysis, and symmetry handling. Last, not least, the report presents updates to other components and extensions of the SCIP Optimization Suite, in particular, the LP solver SoPlex and the mixed-integer semidefinite programming solver SCIP-SDP.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP):

## Definition

Mixed-integer (linear) programming (MIP or MILP) is a problem in which only some of the unknown variables are required to be integers.(no content)If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Applications

Mixed-integer programming has diverse real-world applications, including:

- Industrial productions, including job-shop modelling
- Agricultural production planning to determine production yield for several crops that can share resources (land, labor, capital, seeds, fertilizer, etc.) with the objective of maximizing total production without exceeding available resources
- Service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks, such as assigning buses or subways to individual routes
- Frequency planning in GSM mobile networks using binary variables to indicate whether a frequency is assigned to an antenna

## Solution Methods

Cutting plane methods work by solving the LP relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points.(no content)Branch and bound methods are another class of algorithms, including the branch and cut method that combines both branch and bound and cutting plane methods.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about the key concepts that form Mixed-Integer Semidefinite Programming (MISD):

## Overview

Mixed-integer semidefinite programming combines two important optimization paradigms:

1. **Semidefinite Programming (SDP)**: Semidefinite programming is a subfield of mathematical programming concerned with the optimization of a linear objective function over the intersection of the cone of positive semidefinite matrices with an affine space.

2. **Mixed-Integer Programming**: When some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Properties and Applications

Many practical problems in operations research and combinatorial optimization can be modeled or approximated as semidefinite programming problems. SDPs are in fact a special case of cone programming and can be efficiently solved by interior point methods.

Additionally, all linear programs and (convex) quadratic programs can be expressed as SDPs, which indicates the generality and power of this framework.

## Solvers

Some optimization software packages support various forms of mixed-integer conic programming. For example, MOSEK is a software package for the solution of linear, mixed-integer linear, quadratic, mixed-integer quadratic, quadratically constrained, conic and convex nonlinear mathematical optimization problems.

Mixed-integer semidefinite programming is particularly valuable for handling problems that require both the expressiveness of semidefinite constraints and the discrete decisions needed in many real-world applications.

Links: [{"title":"Benders decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benders_decomposition"},{"title":"FortSP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FortSP"},{"title":"Jacques F. Benders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_F._Benders"},{"title":"Category:Decomposition methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Decomposition_methods"},{"title":"Benders (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benders_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Bender's method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bender's_method"},{"title":"B-Bender - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/StringBender"},{"title":"Decomposition of a module - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decomposition_of_a_module"},{"title":"Benderama - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benderama"},{"title":"Futurama: Bender's Big Score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benders_Big_Score"}]

## Benders Decomposition

Benders decomposition is a technique in mathematical programming that allows the solution of very large linear programming problems that have a special block structure.(no content)This block structure often occurs in applications such as stochastic programming as the uncertainty is usually represented with scenarios.(no content)The technique is named after Jacques F. Benders.

### How It Works

The strategy behind Benders decomposition can be summarized as divide-and-conquer. In Benders decomposition, the variables of the original problem are divided into two subsets so that a first-stage master problem is solved over the first set of variables, and the values for the second set of variables are determined in a second-stage subproblem for a given first-stage solution.(no content)If the subproblem determines that the fixed first-stage decisions are in fact infeasible, then so-called Benders cuts are generated and added to the master problem, which is then re-solved until no cuts can be generated.

### Comparison to Other Methods

Since Benders decomposition adds new constraints as it progresses towards a solution, the approach is called "row generation". In contrast, Dantzig–Wolfe decomposition uses "column generation".

## Benders Decomposition

Benders decomposition is a technique in mathematical programming that allows the solution of very large linear programming problems that have a special block structure.(no content)This block structure often occurs in applications such as stochastic programming as the uncertainty is usually represented with scenarios.(no content)The technique is named after Jacques F. Benders.

### How It Works

The strategy behind Benders decomposition can be summarized as divide-and-conquer. In Benders decomposition, the variables of the original problem are divided into two subsets so that a first-stage master problem is solved over the first set of variables, and the values for the second set of variables are determined in a second-stage subproblem for a given first-stage solution.(no content)If the subproblem determines that the fixed first-stage decisions are in fact infeasible, then so-called Benders cuts are generated and added to the master problem, which is then re-solved until no cuts can be generated.

### Comparison to Other Methods

Since Benders decomposition adds new constraints as it progresses towards a solution, the approach is called "row generation". In contrast, Dantzig–Wolfe decomposition uses "column generation".

## Integer Programming - Search Results

Here's an overview of integer programming based on the search results:

### Definition
An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers.(no content)In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

### Key Variants
- If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.
- 0–1 integer programming or binary integer programming (BIP) is the special case of integer programming where variables are required to be 0 or 1 (rather than arbitrary integers).

### Computational Complexity
Integer programming is NP-complete, and integer programming problems are in many practical situations (those with bounded variables) NP-hard.

### Applications
Integer programming has practical applications in various domains including:
- Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling.
- These problems involve service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks. For example, a problem may involve assigning buses or subways to individual routes so that a timetable can be met.

### Solution Methods
Cutting planes were proposed by Ralph Gomory in the 1950s as a method for solving integer programming and mixed-integer programming problems. Additionally, in the mid-1990s Gérard Cornuéjols and co-workers showed them to be very effective in combination with branch-and-bound (called branch-and-cut).

## Presolving in Optimization

Presolving is a technique used in optimization solvers, particularly in linear programming. A pre-solver can remove redundant variables and remove or tighten constraints from an optimization problem before the main solution algorithm is applied.

The purpose of presolving is to simplify the problem by:
- Eliminating variables that don't affect the optimal solution
- Removing redundant or unnecessary constraints
- Tightening constraint bounds to reduce the search space

This preprocessing step helps improve solver performance by reducing the size and complexity of the problem that the main optimization algorithm needs to solve. For example, Ivet Galabova combined her LP presolve with Julian Hall's simplex crash procedure and Huangfu Qi's dual simplex solver to solve a class of industrial LP problems faster than the best open-source solvers, demonstrating how effective presolving can be in improving practical solver performance.

## Overview

Heuristics are techniques designed for problem solving more quickly when classic methods are too slow for finding an exact or approximate solution, or when classic methods fail to find any exact solution in a search space.(no content)This is achieved by trading optimality, completeness, accuracy, or precision for speed.

## Application in Optimization

In the context of optimization, heuristics may produce results by themselves, or they may be used in conjunction with optimization algorithms to improve their efficiency (e.g., they may be used to generate good seed values).

Web search results for query: "Symmetry group mathematics"

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_group"},{"title":"Symmetric group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_group"},{"title":"Group theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_theory"},{"title":"Molecular symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_symmetry"},{"title":"Group (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Symmetry in mathematics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_in_mathematics"},{"title":"List of planar symmetry groups - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_planar_symmetry_groups"},{"title":"Symmetry (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_(physics)"},{"title":"Symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry"},{"title":"Dihedral group of order 6 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dihedral_group_of_order_6"}]

Here's what I found about symmetry groups in mathematics:

## Definition

In group theory, the symmetry group of a geometric object is the group of all transformations under which the object is invariant, endowed with the group operation of composition.(no content)Such a transformation is an invertible mapping of the ambient space which takes the object to itself, and which preserves all the relevant structure of the object.

## Types of Symmetry Groups

There are also continuous symmetry groups (Lie groups), which contain rotations of arbitrarily small angles or translations of arbitrarily small distances.(no content)An example is O(3), the symmetry group of a sphere.(no content)Continuous symmetries can be described by Lie groups while discrete symmetries are described by finite groups.

## Examples

Common examples include:
- D1 is the 2-element group containing the identity operation and a single reflection, which occurs when the figure has only a single axis of bilateral symmetry, for example the letter "A".
- D3, D4 etc. are the symmetry groups of the regular polygons.
- The dihedral group D3 is the symmetry group of an equilateral triangle, that is, it is the set of all rigid transformations (reflections, rotations, and combinations of these) that leave the shape and position of this triangle fixed.

## Applications

Various physical systems, such as crystals and the hydrogen atom, and three of the four known fundamental forces in the universe, may be modelled by symmetry groups. Thus group theory and the closely related representation theory have many important applications in physics, chemistry, and materials science.

Links: [{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"Branching factor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branching_factor"},{"title":"Branch predictor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_predictor"},{"title":"Edmonds' algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmonds'_algorithm"},{"title":"Restricted representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Restricted_representation"},{"title":"Branching process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branching_process"},{"title":"Binary decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_decision_diagram"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about branching rules algorithms:

## Branch and Bound Algorithms

A branch and bound (B&B) algorithm operates by recursively splitting the search space into smaller spaces and then minimizing the objective function on these smaller spaces; the splitting is called branching.(no content)Branch-and-bound is a method for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller subproblems and using a bounding function to eliminate subproblems that cannot contain the optimal solution.

## Branching Strategies in Optimization

In optimization algorithms like branch and cut, there are various branching strategies used to decide how to partition the search space. An important step in the branch and cut algorithm is the branching step, where there are a variety of branching heuristics that can be used. Some examples include:

- A branching strategy that chooses the variable with the fractional part closest to 0.5.
- Strong branching involves testing which of the candidate variables gives the best improvement to the objective function before actually branching on them.

## Branching in SAT Solving

The DPLL algorithm relies on a Branching Heuristic to pick the next free variable assignment, with different implementations of this heuristic producing markedly different decision trees and having significant effects on the efficiency of the solver.

## Branching Rules in Representation Theory

Branching rules also appear in mathematics: Rules for decomposing the restriction of an irreducible representation into irreducible representations of the subgroup are called branching rules, and have important applications in physics.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of linear programming solvers:

## What is Linear Programming?

Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships.

## Popular Linear Programming Solvers

There are several widely-used solvers available:

**Open-Source Solvers:**
- GLOP (the Google Linear Optimization Package) is Google's open-source linear programming solver written in C++ and released as part of Google's OR-Tools software suite in 2014.
- COIN-OR LP (CLP or Clp) is an open-source linear programming solver written in C++.
- The GNU Linear Programming Kit (GLPK) is a software package intended for solving large-scale linear programming (LP) and mixed integer programming (MIP) problems, organized as a callable library.

**Commercial Solvers:**
- The FICO Xpress optimizer is a commercial optimization solver for linear programming (LP), mixed integer linear programming (MILP), convex quadratic programming (QP), and other related problems.
- Gurobi Optimizer is a solver for linear and quadratic programming with continuous or integer variables (MIP).

**Modeling Languages:**
AMPL (A Mathematical Programming Language) is an algebraic modeling language to describe and solve high-complexity problems for large-scale mathematical computing (e.g. large-scale optimization and scheduling-type problems).

## What is Linear Programming?

Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships.

There are several widely-used solvers available:

**Open-Source Solvers:**
- GLOP (the Google Linear Optimization Package) is Google's open-source linear programming solver written in C++ and released as part of Google's OR-Tools software suite in 2014.
- COIN-OR LP (CLP or Clp) is an open-source linear programming solver written in C++.
- The GNU Linear Programming Kit (GLPK) is a software package intended for solving large-scale linear programming (LP) and mixed integer programming (MIP) problems, organized as a callable library.

**Commercial Solvers:**
- The FICO Xpress optimizer is a commercial optimization solver for linear programming (LP), mixed integer linear programming (MILP), convex quadratic programming (QP), and other related problems.
- Gurobi Optimizer is a solver for linear and quadratic programming with continuous or integer variables (MIP).

**Modeling Languages:**
AMPL (A Mathematical Programming Language) is an algebraic modeling language to describe and solve high-complexity problems for large-scale mathematical computing (e.g. large-scale optimization and scheduling-type problems).

These solvers use various algorithms, with the efficiencies of good implementations of simplex-based methods and interior point methods being similar for routine applications of linear programming.

Web search results for query: "Conflict analysis constraint programming"

Links: [{"title":"Min-conflicts algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Min-conflicts_algorithm"},{"title":"Conflict-driven clause learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict-driven_clause_learning"},{"title":"Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction_problem"},{"title":"Constraint logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_logic_programming"},{"title":"Category:Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Constraint_programming"},{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"Constraint learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_learning"},{"title":"Theory of constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_constraints"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about conflict analysis in constraint programming:

## Key Concepts

Conflict analysis identifies new clauses using the resolution operation. This technique is particularly prominent in SAT solvers and constraint satisfaction algorithms.

### Conflict-Driven Clause Learning (CDCL)

In computer science, conflict-driven clause learning (CDCL) is an algorithm for solving the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT).(no content)Conflict-driven solvers, such as conflict-driven clause learning (CDCL), augment the basic DPLL search algorithm with efficient conflict analysis, clause learning, backjumping, a "two-watched-literals" form of unit propagation, adaptive branching, and random restarts.

### Constraint Learning

In the broader context of constraint satisfaction, in constraint satisfaction backtracking algorithms, constraint learning is a technique for improving efficiency. It works by recording new constraints whenever an inconsistency is found.(no content)Jumpback learning is based on storing as constraints the inconsistent assignments that would be found by conflict-based backjumping. Whenever a partial assignment is found inconsistent, this algorithm selects the violated constraint that is minimal according to an ordering based on the order of instantiation of variables.

### Min-Conflicts Algorithm

Another approach to handling conflicts is a min-conflicts algorithm is a search algorithm or heuristic method to solve constraint satisfaction problems.(no content)Given an initial assignment of values to all the variables of a constraint satisfaction problem (with one or more constraints not satisfied), select a variable from the set of variables with conflicts violating one or more of its constraints. Assign to this variable a value that minimizes the number of conflicts (usually breaking ties randomly). Repeat this process of conflicted variable selection and min-conflict value assignment until a solution is found or a pre-selected maximum number of iterations is reached.

I've successfully completed the web search for "Decomposition algorithms optimization". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Decomposition method is a generic term for solutions of various problems and design of algorithms in which the basic idea is to decompose the problem into subproblems.

## Major Decomposition Approaches in Optimization

**Dantzig–Wolfe Decomposition**: Dantzig–Wolfe decomposition is an algorithm for solving (mixed integer) linear programming problems by exploiting their structure.(no content)The corresponding sub-problem will be a lot smaller than the original problem (less constraints and less variables) which means it can be solved faster. Notably, the algorithm can be implemented such that the subproblems are solved in parallel, since their solutions are completely independent.

**Benders Decomposition**: Benders decomposition is a technique in mathematical programming that allows the solution of very large linear programming problems that have a special block structure.(no content)The strategy behind Benders decomposition can be summarized as divide-and-conquer. That is, in Benders decomposition, the variables of the original problem are divided into two subsets so that a first-stage master problem is solved over the first set of variables, and the values for the second set of variables are determined in a second-stage subproblem for a given first-stage solution.

**Constraint Satisfaction**: In constraint satisfaction, a decomposition method translates a constraint satisfaction problem into another constraint satisfaction problem that is binary and acyclic. Decomposition methods work by grouping variables into sets, and solving a subproblem for each set.

## Applications

These decomposition methods are used across multiple domains including linear programming, constraint satisfaction, graph theory, and matrix operations for solving large-scale optimization problems efficiently.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Summary

✅ **All tasks completed successfully!**

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: Contribution (the paper presents SCIP 7.0 with new features, improvements, and enhancements)

### Triples Extracted and Validated
The analysis identified **10 key entities** from the paper's title and abstract:

**Concepts Used** (4):
- Integer programming
- Linear programming
- Semidefinite programming
- Symmetry group

**Methods Proposed** (5):
- Benders decomposition
- Decomposition method
- Heuristic (computer science)
- Conflict-driven clause learning

**Tasks/Problems Addressed** (1):
- Mixed-integer linear programming

**Methods Used** (1):
- Branch and bound

### Validation Results
✅ All Wikipedia URLs verified
✅ All entity types properly classified
✅ All relations correctly specified (at least 1 "uses" and multiple "proposes" as required for contribution papers)
✅ All relevance statements complete

The triples_output.json file is now complete, validated, and ready for use.
